column4: The problem is, I have two drives, one that easily fits all the content of the other. I would like to keep the contents of the smaller drive as they are, for later inspection, and empty the drive for other uses. I thought it would be best if I could just get the partitions from the smaller drive as files on the larger drive, so that I could directly mount the files when I need to examine the contents (not having to bother with backup/restore). I don't need to wri
(In fact, is it even possible to "mount" a file...?)
I guess I could just copy all the files, but I don't want to clutter the files system, and one of the partitions is ntfs so I figure there might be problems with file names and such.
You can mount files, yes
Are they images of entire drives or one and one partition?
well right now I have 3 partitions, one of them ntfs, that i would like to copy as files (so I can release the hard disk to other uses)
You could just archive them with tar
I was thinking about that... but can I then expolre the tar archive by mountin it? and will tar archive work with possible ntfs file naming schemes?
cd /media/rootoffs1/; sudo tar zcvf /path/to/store/archive.tar.gz .
You can open the archive in the archive manager (by just double-clicking it) and explore what files it contains
will this preserve all the possible ntfs stuff (like permission) as well? with direct copying its at least an exact copy?

And there shouldn't be a problem taring down the files in an ntfs filesystem. The problem would be with extracting to an ntfs filesystem, since it's very picky about what characters you can have in filenames. ext3 accepts every concievable character in filenames, except / and \0
there's also the file permissions
Permissions on NTFS? Is that something new in newer Ubuntu versions?
it's a windows partition
At any rate, when tar is run as root (with sudo), it will preserve file permissions and ownership
NTFS did not have file permissions last time I messed around with such
hmm, windows does have a quite extensive permissions system, but it could of course be with windows itself, not with the file system...
Yeah, those are some ACLs that linux don't see/support. Don't know if they'll be preserved, so it might be best to copy the NTFS from windows.
well if I copy the direct partiton, they'll be presereved. I'd really rather not mess around with windows data copying right now :)
if there is a way to easily copy the entire partition data, that is.
Right, well, then unmount the drive, and make an image of the drive then. sudo dd if=/dev/sda1 of=/path/to/store/partition.img
unmount the windows partition I mean. Then run a dd command like that, replacing /dev/sda1 with the correct inode for your case
yup, thanks! so a simple dd is enough. nice!
